                            <comment id="13439561" author="garydgregory" created="Wed, 22 Aug 2012 14:24:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Feel free to provide a patch based on trunk code &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13442287" author="igorlash" created="Mon, 27 Aug 2012 05:54:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I really like the way of usage of file comparators as described in JavaDoc, so I have changed code. Patch is attached.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13442289" author="igorlash" created="Mon, 27 Aug 2012 05:55:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixing inconsistency between code and JavaDocs.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13443249" author="garydgregory" created="Tue, 28 Aug 2012 16:30:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This patch breaks compatibility so it could only be considered for a major release. I am not sure we want that now.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Fixing the Javadoc to match the code is OK to do in trunk now but this patch does not do that.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;What needs to be decided as usual is if it is the code or the docs that should be fixed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13443834" author="igorlash" created="Wed, 29 Aug 2012 06:04:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This patch will not break backward compatibility. There will be unnecessary cast if someone used comparator in the way &lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;((NameFileComparator)NameFileComparator.NAME_COMPARATOR).sort(list)&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="13444041" author="garydgregory" created="Wed, 29 Aug 2012 13:20:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hm, OK, so the Clirr errors are false positives because the class &lt;tt&gt;AbstractFileComparator&lt;/tt&gt; implements &lt;tt&gt;Comparator&amp;lt;File&amp;gt;&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Source compatibility is clearly OK (unless you count compiler warnings for the type casting case above).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Binary compatibility should be OK too.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13444049" author="garydgregory" created="Wed, 29 Aug 2012 13:29:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Committed revision 1378539. Applied patch and fixed compiler warnings in tests.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13634585" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 17 Apr 2013 23:16:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The change is &lt;b&gt;not binary compatible&lt;/b&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I just compiled the following code against IO 2.4:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;CompTest {
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; void main(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] a) {
        Comparator&amp;lt;File&amp;gt; comparator = DefaultFileComparator.DEFAULT_COMPARATOR;
    }
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This runs fine against &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-2&quot; title=&quot;[IO] FilenameUtils.catPath cannot handle &amp;quot;\&amp;quot;&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-2&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-2&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.4, but when run with 2.5-SNAPSHOT it fails with:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Exception in thread &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;main&quot;&lt;/span&gt; java.lang.NoSuchFieldError: DEFAULT_COMPARATOR
        at CompTest.main(CompTest.java:8)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think this is because the loader looks for the exact field type when trying to find a field. This is similar to the binary incompatibility that results from changing a method return type from void to int or long.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The code is source-compatible.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-336] Yottabyte (YB) incorrectly defined in FileUtils</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-336</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In FileUtils, a yottabyte is currently defined as follows:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static final BigInteger ONE_YB = ONE_ZB.multiply(BigInteger.valueOf(ONE_EB));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I believe this should be:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static final BigInteger ONE_YB = ONE_ZB.multiply(BigInteger.valueOf(ONE_KB));&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12560395">IO-336</key>
            <summary>Yottabyte (YB) incorrectly defined in FileUtils</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[IO-335] Tailer#readLines - incorrect CR handling</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-335</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The readLines method checks for CR. If found, it is not stored immediately, but a flag is set.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If the next char is an LF, the buffer is passed to the listener without the CR.&lt;br/&gt;
As soon as the next non-LF (and non-CR) character is received, the saved CR is written to the buffer.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The net result is that CR before LF migrates to the start of the next non-empty line, and repeated CRs are collapsed. This is clearly wrong.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The original code (before &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-274&quot; title=&quot;Tailer returning partial lines when reaching EOF before EOL&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-274&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-274&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;) used RandomAccessFile#readLine() which returns on CR, LF or CRLF.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It looks as though the intention was to retain this behaviour whilst not blocking.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12559749">IO-335</key>
            <summary>Tailer#readLines - incorrect CR handling</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="sebb">Sebb</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 7 Jun 2012 20:41:57 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 8 Nov 2016 17:57:26 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 7 Jun 2012 23:24:05 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.4</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13777214" author="cltlfcjin" created="Wed, 25 Sep 2013 07:05:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I found tailer still erroneously considers character CR(\r) as line terminator in version 2.4.&lt;br/&gt;
The issue which I will describe is under Linux. When Tailer#readLines receive a character sequence like this &quot;aa\rbb\n&quot;, it will be divided into 2 lines: (It is not what I expect)&lt;br/&gt;
aa&lt;br/&gt;
bb&lt;br/&gt;
However, Linux system use the ASCII character \n(LF) as the newline character, not CR. Wiki about newline(&lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newline&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newline&lt;/a&gt;) also gives some correspondences between OS and line terminator.&lt;br/&gt;
We can see that CR is just used as newline character in Mac OS etc.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One not good solution for the issue is considering it with OS environment. We can keep OS condition in Tailer initial (&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ziben.com.br/java/java-os-name-property-values&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.ziben.com.br/java/java-os-name-property-values&lt;/a&gt;). But I know it is not a good way: The logs which record a Windows application data are coped by  Tailer in Linux.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Anyway, current code causes a problom by CR in Linux. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13777730" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 25 Sep 2013 16:48:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The original bug is fixed (r1347829); the code now treats CR, LF and CRLF as line terminators.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please open a new bug to request a change in this behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13778414" author="cltlfcjin" created="Thu, 26 Sep 2013 03:24:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thank you. But it reminded me that the same approach to terminated a line in  java.io.BufferedReader#readline()&lt;br/&gt;
/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Reads a line of text.  A line is considered to be terminated by any one&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;of a line feed (&apos;\n&apos;), a carriage return (&apos;\r&apos;), or a carriage return&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;followed immediately by a linefeed.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&#8230; */&lt;br/&gt;
     String readLine(boolean ignoreLF) throws IOException {&lt;br/&gt;
             &#8230;&lt;br/&gt;
Perhaps, Java always regard them as the same. I&apos;d better change my own code to adapt to it.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[IO-334] FileUtils.toURLs throws NPE for null parameter; this is inconsistent with toFiles method behaviour</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-334</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The toFiles method treats null input the same as an empty array, however the toURLs method throws NPE for null input.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is inconsistent.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The Javadoc for toURLs does not specify the behaviour for null input.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Either the method should be fixed to treat null as an empty array, or the NPE should be documented.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12559680">IO-334</key>
            <summary>FileUtils.toURLs throws NPE for null parameter; this is inconsistent with toFiles method behaviour</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>

<item>
            <title>[IO-331] BOMInputStream wrongly detects UTF-32LE_BOM files as UTF-16LE_BOM files in method getBOM()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-331</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The BOMInputStream works great for most UTF encoded files when detecting Byte Order Marks. However, if a file is UTF-32LE encoded with BOM the class takes it as UTF-16LE instead. This is not expected behavior.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The problem comes from method getBOM(). And the first two bytes for UTF-16LE and UTF-32LE are the same, which might be the root cause of the problem.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following lists the bytes for UTF encodings for reference. The content is a BOM followed by letter &apos;t&apos;.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&apos;table-wrap&apos;&gt;
&lt;table class=&apos;confluenceTable&apos;&gt;&lt;tbody&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt;Encoding&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt;Byte 1&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt;Byte 2&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt;Byte 3&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt;Byte 4&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;UTF8&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;EF&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;BB&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;BF&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;74&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;UTF16-LE&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;FF&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;FE&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;74&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;UTF16-BE&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;FE&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;FF&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;74&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;UTF32-LE&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;FF&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;FE&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;74&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;UTF32-BE&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;FE&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;FF&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;00&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td class=&apos;confluenceTd&apos;&gt;74&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;



&lt;p&gt;I personally used the following code to work around this problem at the moment. Hope it helps.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;	&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; void detectBOM(InputStream in) &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException{
		List&amp;lt;ByteOrderMark&amp;gt; all=availableBOMs();
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; max=0;
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; (ByteOrderMark bom : all) {
            max = &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Math&lt;/span&gt;.max(max, bom.length());
        }
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;byte&lt;/span&gt;[] firstBytes=&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;byte&lt;/span&gt;[max];
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; (&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; i = 0; i &amp;lt; max; i++) {
			firstBytes[i]=(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;byte&lt;/span&gt;) in.read();
			&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.print(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;.toHexString(firstBytes[i] &amp;amp; 0xff).toUpperCase()+&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot; &quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
		}
		
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; found=&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;;
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; (&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; j = max; j &amp;gt;1; j--) {
			&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;byte&lt;/span&gt;[] _copy=Arrays.copyOf(firstBytes, j);
			&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; (ByteOrderMark mark : all) {
				found=Arrays.equals(_copy, mark.getBytes());
				&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (found) {
					&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;\nBOM is: &quot;&lt;/span&gt;+mark.getCharsetName());
					&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;break&lt;/span&gt;;
				}
			}
			&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (found) &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;break&lt;/span&gt;;
		}
	}
	
	&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; List&amp;lt;ByteOrderMark&amp;gt; availableBOMs(){
		List&amp;lt;ByteOrderMark&amp;gt; all=&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ArrayList&amp;lt;ByteOrderMark&amp;gt;();
		all.add(ByteOrderMark.UTF_8);
		all.add(ByteOrderMark.UTF_16BE);
		all.add(ByteOrderMark.UTF_16LE);
		all.add(ByteOrderMark.UTF_32BE);
		all.add(ByteOrderMark.UTF_32LE);
		&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; all;
	}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;OS: Win 7 x64&lt;br/&gt;
JDK: 1.7.03&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12558913">IO-331</key>
            <summary>BOMInputStream wrongly detects UTF-32LE_BOM files as UTF-16LE_BOM files in method getBOM()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="davidgjm">David Gao</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>BOMInputStream</label>
                            <label>UTF-32LE</label>

<item>
            <title>[IO-329] FileUtils.writeLines uses unbuffered IO</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-329</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FileUtils.writeLines looks like next:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; out = openOutputStream(file, append);&lt;br/&gt;
 IOUtils.writeLines(lines, lineEnding, out, encoding);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;openOutputStream opens plain FileOutputStream without any buffering and IOUtils.writeLines does not add abyt buffering. This means each line require 2 write syscalls (one for the line and one for line separator). This makes call very slow, especially for short lines&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12558328">IO-329</key>
            <summary>FileUtils.writeLines uses unbuffered IO</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="tivv">Vitalii Tymchyshyn</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 28 May 2012 12:11:59 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 8 Nov 2016 17:57:24 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 28 May 2012 13:43:31 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.3</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.4</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Streams/Writers</component>

<item>
            <title>[IO-328] FileUtils.listFilesAndDirs includes original dir in results even when it doesn&apos;t match filter</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-328</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;listFilesAndDirs seems to always include the &quot;directory&quot; passed as input in it&apos;s resulting Collection.  This is unexpected given the docs for the method...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Finds files within a given directory (and optionally its subdirectories). All files found are filtered by an IOFileFilter. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the &quot;given directory&quot; is not a subdirectory of itself&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;it is not subjected to the IOFileFilter dirFilter, it is always added.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12552764">IO-328</key>
            <summary>FileUtils.listFilesAndDirs includes original dir in results even when it doesn&apos;t match filter</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="hossman">Chris M. Hostetter</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 25 Apr 2012 23:50:25 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 11 Oct 2017 12:41:49 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 21 Apr 2013 23:27:36 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.5</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>2</votes>
                                    <watches>4</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13262258" author="hossman" created="Wed, 25 Apr 2012 23:52:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;patch with a testcase demonstrating the core problem&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13289084" author="detinho" created="Tue, 5 Jun 2012 02:02:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In this case, I think it makes more sense to not include the given directory, since the user already knows it and it is beeing validated to be a directory at the beginning of the method.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13633443" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 16 Apr 2013 21:57:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think the Javadoc is correct as it stands, though perhaps a bit ambiguous.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The Javadoc says:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;All files found are filtered by an IOFileFilter.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Directories are not mentioned.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;The resulting collection includes the subdirectories themselves.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That is ambiguous; it should probably read:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;The resulting collection includes the directories themselves.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13637680" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 21 Apr 2013 23:24:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Note also that the starting directory is not subject to the directory filter; the Javadoc says:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;* @param dirFilter  optional filter to apply when finding subdirectories.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13637683" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 21 Apr 2013 23:27:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1470362&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1470362&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;

       Javadoc: clarify that original dir is included in the results&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[IO-323] What should happen in FileUtils.sizeOf[Directory] when an overflow takes place?</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-323</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FileUtils.sizeOf&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;Directory&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; adds longs. What should happen when an overflow happens?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Apache Maven 3.0.4 (r1232337; 2012-01-17 03:44:56-0500)&lt;br/&gt;
Maven home: C:\Java\apache-maven-3.0.4\bin\..&lt;br/&gt;
Java version: 1.6.0_31, vendor: Sun Microsystems Inc.&lt;br/&gt;
Java home: C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_31\jre&lt;br/&gt;
Default locale: en_US, platform encoding: Cp1252&lt;br/&gt;
OS name: &quot;windows 7&quot;, version: &quot;6.1&quot;, arch: &quot;amd64&quot;, family: &quot;windows&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12551055">IO-323</key>
            <summary>What should happen in FileUtils.sizeOf[Directory] when an overflow takes place?</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 16 Apr 2012 13:09:58 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 8 Nov 2016 17:59:14 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 Apr 2013 22:09:24 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.3</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Utilities</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13254733" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 16 Apr 2012 14:50:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;What are the options? I can think of the following:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ol&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;throw a runtime exception&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;ignore the problem&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;return a &quot;special&quot; value, e.g. -1&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ol&gt;


&lt;p&gt;The same problem may apply elsewhere in IO.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13254737" author="garydgregory" created="Mon, 16 Apr 2012 14:52:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hm, how about -1 for the current API and adding an API that uses BigInteger if you really care about huge sizes?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There is no point on keeping on counting once you overflow.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13254927" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 16 Apr 2012 19:04:45 +0000"  >&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;There is no point on keeping on counting once you overflow.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;True, but one has to detect the overflow in the first place.&lt;br/&gt;
This adds extra code for every invocation.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Overflow by upto Long.MAX_VALUE will result in a negative value, so the caller can detect many cases of overflow.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Long.MAX_VALUE + Long.MAX_VALUE =&amp;gt; -2&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So we could opt for option (2), and document the possible overflow.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13254931" author="garydgregory" created="Mon, 16 Apr 2012 19:08:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Ok, we can ignore and document for now.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;How about a BigInteger method that will give you the right answer no matter now big?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Gary&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13254935" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 16 Apr 2012 19:13:40 +0000"  >&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;How about a BigInteger method that will give you the right answer no matter now big?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;File a separate JIRA enhancement request?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13254947" author="garydgregory" created="Mon, 16 Apr 2012 19:29:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;.bq File a separate JIRA enhancement request?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Reasonable, pertinent and in process &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13633472" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 16 Apr 2013 22:09:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1468637&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1468637&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[IO-321] ByteOrderMark UTF_32LE is incorrect</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-321</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ByteOrderMark UTF_32LE is incorrect.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is should be &lt;tt&gt;FF FE 00 00&lt;/tt&gt; not &lt;tt&gt;FE FF 00 00&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Apache Maven 3.0.4 (r1232337; 2012-01-17 03:44:56-0500)&lt;br/&gt;
Maven home: C:\Java\apache-maven-3.0.4\bin\..&lt;br/&gt;
Java version: 1.6.0_31, vendor: Sun Microsystems Inc.&lt;br/&gt;
Java home: C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_31\jre&lt;br/&gt;
Default locale: en_US, platform encoding: Cp1252&lt;br/&gt;
OS name: &quot;windows 7&quot;, version: &quot;6.1&quot;, arch: &quot;amd64&quot;, family: &quot;windows&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
C:\svn\org\apache\commons\trunks-proper\lang&amp;gt;\test\io-320.diff&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-319] FileUtils.sizeOfDirectory follows symbolic links.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-319</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;First of all Thanks tons Apache Commons folks for all the amazing work! &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; My first JIRA. Yayyy. I contributed B-)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A symbolic link may create a cycle and so sizeOfDirectory crashes with an IllegalArgumentException. e.g. &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;$ tree test
test
&#9500;&#9472;&#9472; file
&#9492;&#9472;&#9472; ravi
    &#9500;&#9472;&#9472; cycle -&amp;gt; ../../test
    &#9492;&#9472;&#9472; file
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;causes FileUtils.sizeOfDirectory to crash like so&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;java TestJAVA
Exception in thread &quot;main&quot; java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: &amp;lt;somepath&amp;gt; does not exist
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.sizeOf(FileUtils.java:2053)
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.sizeOfDirectory(FileUtils.java:2089)
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.sizeOf(FileUtils.java:2057)
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.sizeOfDirectory(FileUtils.java:2089)
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.sizeOf(FileUtils.java:2057)
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.sizeOfDirectory(FileUtils.java:2089)
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.sizeOf(FileUtils.java:2057)
        at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.sizeOfDirectory(FileUtils.java:2089)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We faced the same issue in Hadoop &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;. Checkout &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-6963&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-6963&lt;/a&gt; for our solution&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12548889">IO-319</key>
            <summary>FileUtils.sizeOfDirectory follows symbolic links.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="raviprak">Ravi Prakash</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 30 Mar 2012 23:03:51 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 8 Nov 2016 17:57:26 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 16 Apr 2012 13:07:07 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.4</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13249792" author="garydgregory" created="Mon, 9 Apr 2012 12:04:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Can you provide a patch for &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;io&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; trunk please?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13251624" author="raviprak" created="Wed, 11 Apr 2012 14:28:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ll be happy to. I&apos;m working on it now. I&apos;m not sure how platform-independent the test code needs to be, but I&apos;ll give it a fair shot and hopefully you&apos;ll be able to guide me to a better iteration.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13251626" author="garydgregory" created="Wed, 11 Apr 2012 14:30:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Great, thank you Ravi. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13251645" author="raviprak" created="Wed, 11 Apr 2012 14:54:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi Gary,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Could you please review this patch? I wasn&apos;t able to find a way to create symlinks under Windows (FAT doesn&apos;t seem to support it) so the test code only checks under non-windows systems.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13251677" author="garydgregory" created="Wed, 11 Apr 2012 15:33:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;On Windows, the sym link is called an NTFS junction point. This has been available since Windows 2000 according to &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NTFS_symbolic_link&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NTFS_symbolic_link&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;MKLINK [[/D] | [/H] | [/J]] Link Target

        /D      Creates a directory symbolic link.  Default is a file
                symbolic link.
        /H      Creates a hard link instead of a symbolic link.
        /J      Creates a Directory Junction.
        Link    specifies the new symbolic link name.
        Target  specifies the path (relative or absolute) that the new link
                refers to.
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Can you inlude Windows support in your patch? I am on Windows myself.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thank you!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13251730" author="raviprak" created="Wed, 11 Apr 2012 16:53:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the review and pointer Gary! I&apos;ve updated the patch for windows. I&apos;m afraid I do not have a Windows machine to test this on. Could you please?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13251747" author="garydgregory" created="Wed, 11 Apr 2012 17:09:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thank you Ravi, the patch applies and tests OK but... How can this really work when FileUtils.isSymlink(File file) always returns true on Windows?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13251767" author="raviprak" created="Wed, 11 Apr 2012 17:30:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks Gary! Aah! I did not notice that. You probably meant isSymLink always returns false&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Note: the current implementation always returns false if the system is detected as Windows using FilenameUtils#isSystemWindows()&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;causing isSymLink to always be true on Windows. I guess the real fix would be to make the isSymlink() method not do that. Could you please append to the patch and fix it on Windows? I&apos;m sorry I don&apos;t have a Windows machine &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13251777" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 11 Apr 2012 17:45:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Symbolic links are likely to be very rare on Windows.&lt;br/&gt;
IMO it does not matter if the patch does not fix the crash for Windows hosts, so long as it does not otherwise change the behaviour on Windows.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13251779" author="garydgregory" created="Wed, 11 Apr 2012 17:47:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Ok, I&apos;ll plan to apply the patch after 2.3 is out or if 2.3 requires a new RC.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13254667" author="garydgregory" created="Mon, 16 Apr 2012 13:07:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In SVN.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-311] IOUtils.read(InputStream/Reader) ignores the offset parameter</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-311</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;IOUtils.read(InputStream input, byte[] buffer, int offset, int length) and&lt;br/&gt;
read(Reader input, char[] buffer, int offset, int length) don&apos;t take the &lt;br/&gt;
offset parameter into account...&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12547308">IO-311</key>
            <summary>IOUtils.read(InputStream/Reader) ignores the offset parameter</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="rcmuir">Robert Muir</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 20 Mar 2012 23:18:26 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 29 Mar 2012 21:27:26 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 22 Mar 2012 21:13:25 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Utilities</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13235699" author="mikemccand" created="Thu, 22 Mar 2012 16:40:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Maybe this bug should be fixed before releasing 2.2?  It&apos;s fairly nasty.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When used this method (readFully) in Lucene, the bug (completely ignoring the offset parameter) caused immediate failures in our tests.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, this is new code in 2.2 I think?  I see one other readFully in 2.1 (in SwappedDataInputStream), and it looks correct (respects the incoming offset).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13236039" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 22 Mar 2012 21:13:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13241794" author="garydgregory" created="Thu, 29 Mar 2012 21:27:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Version 2.2 has been released and addresses this issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                <issuelinks>

                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">

                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>1.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

            <title>[IO-307] ReaderInputStream#read(byte[] b, int off, int len) should check for valid parameters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-307</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If the buffer is null, the method should throw NPE immediately (rather than letting it occur later)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If the offset or length are &amp;lt; 0 or would overflow the buffer, then throw IndexOutOfBoundsException with details of the values.&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[IO-306] ReaderInputStream#read(byte[] b, int off, int len) should always return 0 for length == 0</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-306</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The method read(byte[] b, int off, int len) should always return 0 if the requested length == 0, even if the stream is empty or at EOF, as that is how the overridden java.io.InputStream method is documented to behave.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12546263">IO-306</key>
            <summary>ReaderInputStream#read(byte[] b, int off, int len) should always return 0 for length == 0</summary>

<item>
            <title>[IO-304] The second constructor of Tailer  class does not pass &apos;delay&apos; to the third one</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-304</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Here is the second contructor of Tailer class:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; Tailer(File file, TailerListener listener, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;long&lt;/span&gt; delay) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt;(file, listener, 1000, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;);
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12544731">IO-304</key>
            <summary>The second constructor of Tailer  class does not pass &apos;delay&apos; to the third one</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

<item>
            <title>[IO-303] TeeOutputStream does not call branch.close() when main.close() throws an exception</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-303</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;TeeOutputStream.close() looks like this:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;TeeOutputStream.java&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    /**
     * Closes both streams. 
     * @&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; an I/O error occurs
     */
    @Override
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void close() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;super&lt;/span&gt;.close();
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt;.branch.close();
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; 

&lt;p&gt;It is obvious that &lt;tt&gt;this.branch.close()&lt;/tt&gt; is not executed when &lt;tt&gt;super.close()&lt;/tt&gt; raises an exception. &lt;tt&gt;super.close()&lt;/tt&gt; may in fact raise an IOException since &lt;tt&gt;ProxyOutputStream.handleIOException(IOException)&lt;/tt&gt; is not overridden.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12543033">IO-303</key>
            <summary>TeeOutputStream does not call branch.close() when main.close() throws an exception</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="fabian.barney">Fabian Barney</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>close</label>
                            <label>stream</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 17 Feb 2012 09:20:19 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 25 Feb 2012 23:50:02 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 17 Feb 2012 20:51:03 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Streams/Writers</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13210275" author="garydgregory" created="Fri, 17 Feb 2012 13:56:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If both close() methods throw an exception, which exception does the method throw? I am guessing the first.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13210346" author="fabian.barney" created="Fri, 17 Feb 2012 15:58:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In my code I prefer throwing the first one. There is one exception when a latter Throwable occurrs and it is an Error and the former not.&lt;br/&gt;
In my opinion this is the Throwable you want to see.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Another approach is to throw something like a MultiIOException containing all occurred exceptions.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I agree that this all is not a real pleasure, but better than leaving resources open that can be closed successfully.&lt;br/&gt;
I&apos;ve written a MultiOutputStream yesterday: &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/fabian-barney/Utils/blob/master/utils/src/com/barney4j/utils/io/MultiOutputStream.java&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/fabian-barney/Utils/blob/master/utils/src/com/barney4j/utils/io/MultiOutputStream.java&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am not sure for myself that I made the right decision here.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13210545" author="garydgregory" created="Fri, 17 Feb 2012 20:51:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is the solution I implemented. For simplicity&apos;s sake, note that the exception thrown is the last exception encountered.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    /**
     * Closes both output streams.
     * 
     * If closing the main output stream &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; an exception, attempt to close the branch output stream.
     * 
     * If closing the main and branch output streams both &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throw&lt;/span&gt; exceptions, which exceptions is thrown by &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt; method is
     * currently unspecified and subject to change.
     * 
     * @&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException
     *             &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; an I/O error occurs
     */
    @Override
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void close() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException {        
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;try&lt;/span&gt; {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;super&lt;/span&gt;.close();
        } &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;catch&lt;/span&gt; (IOException e) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt;.branch.close();
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throw&lt;/span&gt; e;
        }
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt;.branch.close();
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13210625" author="fabian.barney" created="Fri, 17 Feb 2012 22:33:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for addressing this issue that fast! &lt;br/&gt;
Here&apos;s how I would write it but it is just a matter of taste...&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;    @Override
    public void close() throws IOException {        
        try {
            super.close();
        } 
        finally {
            this.branch.close();
        }
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; </comment>
                            <comment id="13210651" author="garydgregory" created="Fri, 17 Feb 2012 23:05:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks reasonable, re-implemented in SVN as above.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13210654" author="garydgregory" created="Fri, 17 Feb 2012 23:07:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;YW. &lt;br/&gt;
BTW, feel free to contribute patches and to improve the test coverage too! &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-302] ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException in BOMInputStream when reading a file without BOM multiple times</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-302</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Resetting the BOMInputStream doesn&apos;t reset the &lt;em&gt;fbLength&lt;/em&gt; member variable. This causes &lt;em&gt;fbLength&lt;/em&gt; to grow bigger than the &lt;em&gt;firstBytes&lt;/em&gt; array (when the file doesn&apos;t contain a BOM), which leads to an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException in the &lt;em&gt;readFirstBytes&lt;/em&gt; method.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The attached test case reveals the problem.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Win7 64bit, Java 6 32bit&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12542374">IO-302</key>
            <summary>ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException in BOMInputStream when reading a file without BOM multiple times</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[IO-300] FileUtils.moveDirectoryToDirectory removes source directory if destination is a subdirectory</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-300</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Since moveDirectoryToDirectory performs a copy then delete, if you specify a target directory that is a subdirectory of the source, everything under the source directory is deleted.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Steps to recreate:&lt;br/&gt;
        File dest = new File(&quot;/tmp/dir1/dir2&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        File src  = new File(&quot;/tmp/dir1/&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        dest.mkdirs();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        System.out.println(src.exists());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        FileUtils.moveDirectoryToDirectory(src, dest, false);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        System.out.println(src.exists());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Output:&lt;br/&gt;
 true&lt;br/&gt;
 false&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you try the same thing with a move command on Linux, you receive: &quot;mv: cannot move `dir1/&apos; to a subdirectory of itself, `dir1/dir2/dir1&apos;&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Maybe throw an exception if dest.getCanonicalPath().startsWith(src.getCanonicalPath())&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12539052">IO-300</key>
            <summary>FileUtils.moveDirectoryToDirectory removes source directory if destination is a subdirectory</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="striderapache">dennis lucero</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 19 Jan 2012 22:06:08 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 29 Mar 2012 21:28:17 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 14 Mar 2012 02:51:30 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13207766" author="thdamp" created="Tue, 14 Feb 2012 15:06:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;With this patch, you can move the directory to any directory, even to a directory which exists inside the source directory.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Patch Logic:&lt;br/&gt;
------------&lt;br/&gt;
1. If the source directory lies on the destination directory, a temporary source directory will be created (inside the system temporary folder). &lt;br/&gt;
2. Deletes original source directory. &lt;br/&gt;
3. Move from temporary source directory to the destination directory as per the usual way.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13228907" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 14 Mar 2012 02:51:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the report.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Added check for subdirectory if rename fails.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13241798" author="garydgregory" created="Thu, 29 Mar 2012 21:28:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Version 2.2 has been released and addresses this issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[IO-299] getPrefixLength returns null if filename has leading slashes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-299</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Situation:&lt;br/&gt;
FilenameUtils.getPrefixLength is used in FilenameUtils.doNormalize.&lt;br/&gt;
FilenameUtils.normalize(&quot;////I don&apos;t want to become null!&quot;) returns null.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Problem:&lt;br/&gt;
Expected was: &quot;I don&apos;t want to become null!&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
The method FilenameUtils.getPrefixLength returns -1 for the mentioned string.&lt;br/&gt;
The root problem is found in following lines of code:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;FilenameUtils.getPrefixLength&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;...
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; posUnix = filename.indexOf(UNIX_SEPARATOR, 2);
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; posWin = filename.indexOf(WINDOWS_SEPARATOR, 2);
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; ((posUnix == -1 &amp;amp;&amp;amp; posWin == -1) || posUnix == 2 || posWin == 2) {
                    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; -1;
                }
...
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Solution:&lt;br/&gt;
All leading slashes should be ignored at all, but considering the rest of the string.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12538613">IO-299</key>
            <summary>getPrefixLength returns null if filename has leading slashes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="latrine">Rick Latrine</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 17 Jan 2012 09:57:57 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 8 Nov 2016 17:59:15 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 22 Apr 2013 17:52:42 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0.1</version>
                    <version>2.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Utilities</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                    <timeoriginalestimate seconds="7200">2h</timeoriginalestimate>
                            <timeestimate seconds="7200">2h</timeestimate>
                                        <comments>
                            <comment id="13206439" author="thdamp" created="Sun, 12 Feb 2012 16:06:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In this case for your input &quot;////I don&apos;t want to become null!&quot;, I think the expected output should be&lt;br/&gt;
In Unix: &lt;br/&gt;
&quot;//I don&apos;t want to become null!&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In Windows: &lt;br/&gt;
Same with the other slash&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Any ideas on this?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13206766" author="joehni" created="Mon, 13 Feb 2012 09:10:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Slashes in Unix are merged, so &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;ls ////////tmp&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt; is actually &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;ls /tmp&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13206805" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 13 Feb 2012 11:05:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The Javadoc says clearly that Unix and Windows are treated the same, also that invalid names return null.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Although double-slashes are collapsed to a single slash, this does not apply at the start of a path, because there they are used for UNC names in Windows.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As far as I can tell, the current behaviour is correct, because UNC paths must have a valid server name.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The Javadoc should probably be updated to clarify this; it would help to add some examples (and test cases if necessary).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13638221" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 22 Apr 2013 17:52:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Updated Javadoc and test cases; current behaviour is correct.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1470636&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1470636&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-299&quot; title=&quot;getPrefixLength returns null if filename has leading slashes&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-299&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-299&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;  getPrefixLength returns null if filename has leading slashes&lt;br/&gt;
        Javadoc: add examples to show correct behaviour; add unit tests&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Modified:&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/io/trunk/src/changes/changes.xml&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/io/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/io/FilenameUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/io/trunk/src/test/java/org/apache/commons/io/FilenameUtilsTestCase.java&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[IO-295] FileUtils.isSymlinks misses symlink folders on Windows</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-295</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I created a symlink folder via mklink.&lt;br/&gt;
Then, while debugging, I noticed that FileUtils.isSymlink() returns false on this directory, while Java 7&apos;s Files.isSymbolicLink() returns true.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows 7 64 bit, Oracle Java 7&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12536566">IO-295</key>
            <summary>FileUtils.isSymlinks misses symlink folders on Windows</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/reopened.png" description="This issue was once resolved, but the resolution was deemed incorrect. From here issues are either marked assigned or resolved.">Reopened</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ripper234">Ron Gross</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 29 Dec 2011 10:50:12 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 26 Feb 2021 20:43:44 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>2.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>5</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13228909" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 14 Mar 2012 03:01:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;At present, the method always returns false for Windows systems.&lt;br/&gt;
Not sure whether it&apos;s possible to detect symbolic links on Windows (except by using Java 7 of course).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13232074" author="detinho" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 21:35:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I thought a, in my opinion, workaround implementation: on windows, execute a dir command on the symlink and check if it contains &amp;lt;SYMLINK&amp;gt; or &amp;lt;SYMLINKD&amp;gt; (for files and directories).&lt;br/&gt;
I attached a prototype patch. If the idea get accepted, I&apos;ll work to improve the patch (maybe use commons exec?).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13232280" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 18 Mar 2012 14:28:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s far from ideal using a command shell for this, but if it is the only way it might be worth it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The class FileSystemUtils currently uses the same approach for getting the system free space, so if it is necessary to use a shell, we can re-use the process code from that class.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13232368" author="detinho" created="Sun, 18 Mar 2012 21:14:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A new patch.&lt;br/&gt;
Moved the shell execution code to a new package protected class ExecUtils.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13633679" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 17 Apr 2013 02:10:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks like DIR does not list symlinks without adding either * or ? to the end of the path.&lt;br/&gt;
This means that the DIR command may return details for other symbolic links that happen to match the wildard expression.&lt;br/&gt;
The suggested patch would need enhancing to prevent false matches.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13637473" author="bayard" created="Sun, 21 Apr 2013 04:42:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;How about an (if JAVA_7) return isSymbolicLink at the top of our method?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13638204" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 22 Apr 2013 17:39:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s little point fixing this now; Java 7 users can just use java.nio.file.Files.isSymbolicLink(Path path) which works for all OSes&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13959139" author="werickson" created="Thu, 3 Apr 2014 19:57:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I disagree.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Apache Commons code also calls this flawed implementation instead of calling java.nio.file.Files.isSymbolicLink.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here&apos;s an example:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/commons-io/commons-io/2.4/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.java/#1529&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/commons-io/commons-io/2.4/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.java/#1529&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In this particular case calling deleteDirectory() in windows will give vastly different results than it does in Linux/Unix&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you&apos;re going to tell people to stop using this implementation, you should also follow your own advice, and stop using it internally too.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13959286" author="sguillory6" created="Thu, 3 Apr 2014 21:50:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Guys,&lt;br/&gt;
     This is not a Windows only issue. This bit us today in our CI build on an Ubuntu build node. In migrating our build nodes, we moved to a raid disk array, and starting using symbolic links to keep our build configs the same, and a number of unit tests starting failing due to FileUtils.isSymbolicLink() falsely reporting that leaf file was a symbolic link.&lt;br/&gt;
     I agree with Will Erickson. The Commons IO FileUtils.deleteDirectory() is calling the defective method and should be fixed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13965140" author="bayard" created="Thu, 10 Apr 2014 08:57:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Reopening per the comments.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="17291737" author="msi" created="Fri, 26 Feb 2021 16:17:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Please also note that on Windows there are symlinks AND &quot;junctions&quot;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/hard-links-and-junctions&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/hard-links-and-junctions&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And &lt;tt&gt;java.nio.file.Files.isSymbolicLink()&lt;/tt&gt; is not detecting junctions. To detect them, you should check for file attributes of given &lt;tt&gt;Path&lt;/tt&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;
Path p = Paths.get(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;C:\\some\\path&quot;&lt;/span&gt;)
BasicFileAttributes attrs = Files.readAttributes(p, BasicFileAttributes.class, LinkOption.NOFOLLOW_LINKS);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; isJunction = attrs.isDirectory() &amp;amp;&amp;amp; attrs.isOther();
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;^Above solution suggested &lt;a href=&quot;https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8031083?focusedCommentId=13444574&amp;amp;page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-13444574&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;here on JDK JIRA&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

</comment>
                            <comment id="17291916" author="garydgregory" created="Fri, 26 Feb 2021 20:43:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yeah... checking for &quot;something that is both a directory AND is other&quot; does not scream &quot;I am a junction&quot; with confidence. This would also need a check for &quot;This file system is on Windows&quot;.&#160;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12518853" name="IO-295-1.patch" size="9448" author="detinho" created="Sun, 18 Mar 2012 21:14:39 +0000"/>
                            <attachment id="12518809" name="IO-295.patch" size="1591" author="detinho" created="Sat, 17 Mar 2012 21:35:52 +0000"/>
