<item>
            <title>[IO-260] ClassLoaderObjectInputStream does not handle Proxy classes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-260</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ObjectInputSteam has 2 methods that need to be overloaded for proper behavior in this case.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;resolveClass is ok, but resolveProxyClass doesn&apos;t attempt to look in the passed class loader to resolve the interfaces.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12497634">IO-260</key>
            <summary>ClassLoaderObjectInputStream does not handle Proxy classes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="johnyoh">John Carrino</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 3 Feb 2011 22:59:18 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 10 Oct 2011 15:48:34 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 12 Mar 2011 01:14:45 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Utilities</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>

<item>
            <title>[IO-258] XmlStreamReader consumes the stream during encoding detection</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-258</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;XmlStreamReader reads the underlying InputStream to try and detect the encoding. However once that process is done the bytes read from the stream should still be available to be read - this was accidentally broken in r1004882 by creating the underlying reader with the original InputStream, rather than the wrapped streams used to detect encoding.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12493941">IO-258</key>
            <summary>XmlStreamReader consumes the stream during encoding detection</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

<item>
            <title>[IO-257] BOMInputStream.read(byte[]) can return 0 which it should not</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-257</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;BOMInputStream.read(byte[]) returns 0 when it should return -1.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is not a valid action (unless buf.length == 0) and can cause problems, e.g. &quot;java.io.IOException: Underlying input stream returned zero bytes - at sun.nio.cs.StreamDecoder.readBytes(StreamDecoder.java:268)&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;From java.io.InputStream.read(byte[]) JavaDocs: &quot;If the length of b is zero, then no bytes are read and 0 is returned; otherwise, there is an attempt to read at least one byte. If no byte is available because the stream is at the end of the file, the value -1 is returned; otherwise, at least one byte is read and stored into b.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Suggested fix, change line 287 of BOMInputStream.java from&lt;br/&gt;
        return (secondCount &amp;lt; 0) ? firstCount : firstCount + secondCount;&lt;br/&gt;
into&lt;br/&gt;
        return (secondCount &amp;lt; 0) ? (firstCount &amp;gt; 0 ? firstCount : -1) : firstCount + secondCount;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12493826">IO-257</key>
            <summary>BOMInputStream.read(byte[]) can return 0 which it should not</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="teme">Teemu L&#229;ng</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 22 Dec 2010 03:13:21 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 18:09:36 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 22 Dec 2010 23:06:21 +0000</resolved>

                        <due></due>

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1052095&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1052095&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-254] FileUtils.contentEquals returns true for equal file names, but file is actually not existing</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-254</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;It is said in the documentation, that:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;This method checks to see if the two files are different lengths or if they point to the same file, before resorting to byte-by-byte comparison of the contents. &quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Does it make sense to return true when the file does not exist even if comparison of a file to itself was attempted?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;windows and linux&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12478323">IO-254</key>
            <summary>FileUtils.contentEquals returns true for equal file names, but file is actually not existing</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dmitry_key">Dmitry Kan</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 26 Oct 2010 10:31:23 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 18:09:33 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 23 Dec 2010 00:46:16 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12974453" author="niallp" created="Thu, 23 Dec 2010 00:46:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The main purpose of this method is to compare the contents of files which do exist. It needs to gracefully handle non-existent files, which it does. Its an edge case comparing the content of two non-existent files and you could argue it either way. Its worked this way since IO 1.0 and the comment in the code clearly indicates it was intentional and therefore I don&apos;t think we should be changed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[IO-253] Test Failures using IBM JDK</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-253</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;J&#246;rg Schaible reports the following test failures in RC5 of Commons IO 2.0&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://markmail.org/message/eoo5bk6n3pfsvfwk&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://markmail.org/message/eoo5bk6n3pfsvfwk&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;&quot;IBM JDK 1.5 does not like the OOME handling in the FileCleanerTestCase and FileCleanerTrackingTestCase, while IBM JDK 1.6 has problems with the WriterOutputStream handling UTF16.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12477586">IO-253</key>
            <summary>Test Failures using IBM JDK</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 17 Oct 2010 22:42:44 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sun, 23 Apr 2017 17:53:14 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 23 Apr 2017 17:53:14 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.5</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12921916" author="niallp" created="Sun, 17 Oct 2010 22:58:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I managed to download IBM&apos;s 1.6 JDK version (eclipse bundle, which is the only windows one available for me) from the following location:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/java/jdk/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/java/jdk/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;I can reproduce the problem with the UTF16 test in WriterOutputStream handling. From debugging, the last call to CharsetDecoder&apos;s  decode(decoderIn, decoderOut, endOfInput) method where the &lt;b&gt;endOfInput&lt;/b&gt; parameter is &lt;b&gt;true&lt;/b&gt; (called by the close() method) causes the CharBuffer&apos;s position to be reset to zero. As a result the flushOutput() method does nothing.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Why this happens only for UTF-16 I don&apos;t know. The source code for the IBM JDK is not available and so it is not possible to determine what exactly its doing. WriterOutputStream is correctly implementing the contract with CharsetDecoder by calling the decode() method a final time, indicating endOfInput and so my conclusion is this is a bug in the IBM JDK.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t have access to IBM&apos;s JDK 1.5 and so theres nothing I can do to look at the failing FileCleaningTracker tests. These tests though fill up memory to try and get the garbage collector to reclaim some PhantomReferences. Once the garbage collector does that, then the tests check the functionality of FileCleaningTracker. The test failing with an OutOfMemory error means that the test is not operating properly and never getting to the point of actually testing FileCleaningTracker. Therefore it doesn&apos;t tell us anything about whether FileCleaningTracker works or not on IBM&apos;s JDK 1.5.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12921922" author="niallp" created="Sun, 17 Oct 2010 23:24:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have added WriterOutputStream tests for UTF-16BE and UTF-16LE - which pass using IBM JDK 1.6. I also added a &quot;buffered&quot; test for UTF-16 which fails on IBM JDK 1.6.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For the record, the following is the output from the tests on IBM JDK:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;

                            <comment id="12929302" author="niallp" created="Sun, 7 Nov 2010 00:32:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I tried Harmony 6.0M3 but the WriterOutputStream tests all pass&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13117039" author="joehni" created="Thu, 29 Sep 2011 06:28:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Just for the record. The current IBM JDK 6 (1.6.0.9 Linux/x64) has improved, but still fails for UTF-16 only. UTF-16LE and UTF16-BE is handled properly. It might be that UTF-16 defaults here to UTF-16LE although Javadoc specifies UTF-16BE in this case (see Javadoc java.nio.Charset).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;testUTF16WithSingleByteWrite(org.apache.commons.io.output.WriterOutputStreamTest):

<item>
            <title>[IO-252] NumberFormatException from FileUtils.toFile method</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-252</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Certain strings can cause the org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.toFile(URL url) method to call Integer.parseInt with an invalid argument and thus throw a NumberFormatException:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Exception in thread &quot;main&quot; java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: &quot;%2&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.lang.NumberFormatException.forInputString(NumberFormatException.java:48)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.lang.Integer.parseInt(Integer.java:449)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.toFile(FileUtils.java:476)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One example of such a string: &quot;both%20are%20100%20%25%20true&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12477297">IO-252</key>
            <summary>NumberFormatException from FileUtils.toFile method</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[IO-248] getFullPathNoEndSeparator return empty while path is one level directory</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-248</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;the getFullPathNoEndSeparator method in FilenameUtils.java (Revision 736890) &lt;br/&gt;
if filename=&quot;/&quot; return &quot;/&quot; &amp;lt;&amp;lt;==right&lt;br/&gt;
if filename=&quot;/abc&quot; return empty &amp;lt;&amp;lt;==bug&lt;br/&gt;
if filename=&quot;/abc/xyz&quot; return &quot;/abc&quot; &amp;lt;&amp;lt;==right &lt;/p&gt;


&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;885 	&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; index = indexOfLastSeparator(filename);
886 	&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (index &amp;lt; 0) {
887 		&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; filename.substring(0, prefix);
888 	}
889 	&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; end = index + (includeSeparator ? 1 : 0);
================
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt;(end==0) &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;/&quot;&lt;/span&gt;;
&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;
890 	&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; filename.substring(0, end);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;linux 2.6.x 32bit java version 1.6.0_20 OpenJDK &lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-246] FilenameUtils.wildcardMatch gives incorrect results</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-246</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This wildcard pattern &quot;*?&quot; does not match correctly. The command:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;System.out.println(FilenameUtils.wildcardMatch(&quot;aaa&quot;, &quot;*?&quot;));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;prints out &quot;false&quot;, even though it matches. The wildcard mask is a bit unusal, but not incorrect. It should match any input with at least one character.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;any&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12470151">IO-246</key>
            <summary>FilenameUtils.wildcardMatch gives incorrect results</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="vva">vva</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 26 Jul 2010 09:17:55 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 18:09:34 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 29 Sep 2010 11:29:20 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Filters</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12915781" author="niallp" created="Tue, 28 Sep 2010 15:16:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;While you&apos;re probably right that using &quot;*?&quot; in a wildcard expression should work as you expect - it would be difficult to fix wildcardMatch() to cater for this.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Using &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;?*&quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt; effectively means the same thing - unfortunately this does not work either - but its much easier to fix. Also in my mind its more precise. For example an expression like &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;aa?*&quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt; always means &quot;any character in the third position&quot; for the &quot;?&quot; wildcard.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12916110" author="niallp" created="Wed, 29 Sep 2010 11:29:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed, &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1002582&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1002582&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[IO-245] FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceKb fail and causes to reboot the machine</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-245</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;My application server is running as windows service. One of it&apos;s components - responsible check free disk space  Then it call to FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceKb(path) - throws IO Exception and server shutting down: &lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 23:25:03,535 ERROR &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;ManagementLog&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Filed to check server free disk space. &lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | java.io.IOException: Command line returned OS error code &apos;128&apos; for command &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;cmd.exe, /C, dir /-c D:&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at org.apache.commons.io.FileSystemUtils.performCommand(FileSystemUtils.java:419)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at org.apache.commons.io.FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceWindows(FileSystemUtils.java:225)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at org.apache.commons.io.FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceOS(FileSystemUtils.java:194)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at org.apache.commons.io.FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceKb(FileSystemUtils.java:166)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at com.proficiency.cg.core.utils.job.ServerDiskSpaceChecker.isDiskSpaceAvailable(ServerDiskSpaceChecker.java:151)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at com.proficiency.cg.core.utils.job.ServerDiskSpaceChecker.perform(ServerDiskSpaceChecker.java:93)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at org.jboss.varia.scheduler.Scheduler$Listener.handleNotification(Scheduler.java:1221)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor3.invoke(Unknown Source)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:585)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at org.jboss.mx.notification.NotificationListenerProxy.invoke(NotificationListenerProxy.java:138)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at $Proxy9.handleNotification(Unknown Source)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at javax.management.NotificationBroadcasterSupport.handleNotification(NotificationBroadcasterSupport.java:221)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at javax.management.NotificationBroadcasterSupport.sendNotification(NotificationBroadcasterSupport.java:184)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at javax.management.timer.Timer.sendNotification(Timer.java:1295)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at javax.management.timer.Timer.notifyAlarmClock(Timer.java:1264)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at javax.management.timer.TimerAlarmClock.run(Timer.java:1347)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at java.util.TimerThread.mainLoop(Timer.java:512)&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:03 | 	at java.util.TimerThread.run(Timer.java:462)&lt;br/&gt;
STATUS | wrapper  | 2010/06/02 23:25:16 | Machine is shutting down.&lt;br/&gt;
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2010/06/02 23:25:16 | 23:25:16,754 INFO  &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;Server&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; JBoss SHUTDOWN: Undeploying all packages&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Win 2003 64-bit, JSDK 1.5 update 6.&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12466281">IO-245</key>
            <summary>FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceKb fail and causes to reboot the machine</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="pavelmmel">Pavel Melech</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>FileSystemUtils</label>
                            <label>freeSpaceKb</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 6 Jun 2010 08:35:45 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 21 Jul 2010 17:00:52 +0000</updated>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12876034" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 6 Jun 2010 10:41:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Has this happened very often? Or just the once?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;According to &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;, error code 128 means:  ERROR_WAIT_NO_CHILDREN - There are no child processes to wait for.&lt;br/&gt;
Not sure why this should happen here - maybe the OS shell terminated abruptly.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, it seems to me that the caller &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; should be able to handle the error without shutting the system down.&lt;br/&gt;
Errors sometimes happen when calling external processes; applications should be able to handle these gracefully.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In this case I would expect it to log an error, and continue.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;May I suggest you try running a stand-alone program that calls FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceKb() every so often, and see what happens?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms681382%28VS.85%29.aspx&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms681382%28VS.85%29.aspx&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; com.proficiency.cg.core.utils.job.ServerDiskSpaceChecker.isDiskSpaceAvailable&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12876035" author="pavelmmel" created="Sun, 6 Jun 2010 11:34:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I saw it on two different customer sites (the same configuration). I think we have a problem here.&lt;br/&gt;
According to call to caller error handling: The cal to FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceKb wrapped by try - catch and it can&apos;t be issue.&lt;br/&gt;
I can to make something then I catch the exception (this is not a problem), but all the system going to reboot !!!!!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12876036" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 6 Jun 2010 11:55:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes, I think you do have a problem, but as far as I can tell it is not in Commons IO, more likely in ServerDiskSpaceChecker.java.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Are you sure it is catching IOException?&lt;br/&gt;
And if so, what is it doing with the Exceptiion?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Are you sure it is not reporting a fatal error, which is then being treated by JBoss as requiring shutdown?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12876037" author="pavelmmel" created="Sun, 6 Jun 2010 12:02:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Maybe.....&lt;br/&gt;
Can you tell me where is the problem here:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    private boolean isDiskSpaceAvailable() {&lt;br/&gt;
        try {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            freeSpaceInMB = (FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceKb(serverWorkDir)) / 1024;&lt;br/&gt;
            if (freeSpaceInMB &amp;lt; diskSpaceBuffer) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                systemLogger.info(&quot;The freeDiskSpaceBuffer is &quot; + diskSpaceBuffer + &quot; and available disk Space InMB &quot; + freeSpaceInMB);
                return false;
            }
&lt;p&gt;        } catch (Exception e) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            systemLogger.error(&quot;Filed to check server free disk space. &quot;, e);
            return false;
        }
&lt;p&gt;        return true;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is a method from ServerDiskSpaceChecker. The exception throws from first line after try.....&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12876038" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 6 Jun 2010 12:42:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Clearly the Exception is being caught, because the (misspelled) log message is shown in the stack trace.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are two possibilities here:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Either the JBoss server notices the systemLogger.error call, and decides to shutdown.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Or the caller notices that there is no diskspace left (return false) and decides to shutdown.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Again, this is a problem with the application, not Commons IO.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12876040" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 6 Jun 2010 12:43:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is not a problem in Commons IO.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-243] SwappedDataInputStream readBoolean is inverted</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-243</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The method readBoolean in SwappedDataInputStream returns true when the byte is zero, false otherwise. In accordance with the contract in java.io.DataInput, true should indicate a non-zero byte. SwappedDataInputStream is for reading Little Endian formats, it should not change the boolean value of individual bytes.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12461076">IO-243</key>
            <summary>SwappedDataInputStream readBoolean is inverted</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="raymyers">Ray Myers</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 3 Apr 2010 00:35:50 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 18:09:33 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 8 Sep 2010 17:16:40 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.0</version>
                    <version>1.1</version>
                    <version>1.2</version>
                    <version>1.3</version>
                    <version>1.3.1</version>
                    <version>1.3.2</version>
                    <version>1.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Streams/Writers</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>

                            <timeestimate seconds="600">10m</timeestimate>

<item>
            <title>[IO-241] CompositeFileComparator(Comparator&lt;File&gt;... delegates) - Using varargs for non-reifiable type goes against type-safety</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-241</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The constructor CompositeFileComparator(Comparator&amp;lt;File&amp;gt;... delegates)  cannot be used without generating a Type safety warning.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is because the type is not reifiable.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is a new class, so I suggest this constructor is replaced with something that supports type-safety, for example List.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12458405">IO-241</key>
            <summary>CompositeFileComparator(Comparator&lt;File&gt;... delegates) - Using varargs for non-reifiable type goes against type-safety</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 7 Mar 2010 22:24:27 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 18:09:35 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 28 Sep 2010 12:40:36 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12895465" author="niallp" created="Wed, 4 Aug 2010 23:16:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The class already has a constructor which takes an Iterable - so that already covers Lists and more. The varargs constructor is convenient and just because it generates a warning in an IDE isn&apos;t IMO a good enough reason to remove it.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12915725" author="niallp" created="Tue, 28 Sep 2010 12:40:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Resolving this as WONTFIX&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[IO-240] FileFilterUtils can create cvsFilter and svnFilter more than once</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-240</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FileFilterUtils lazily creates the static fields cvsFilter and svnFilter; however access to the fields is not synchronized and the fields are not volatile.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One thread can create the filter, but the updated value won&apos;t necessarily be seen by any/all other threads.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This means that the fields can be created multiple times.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Possible solutions: make the fields volatile, or use the singleton IODH idiom. The latter uses a bit more code, but is probably marginally cheaper if the field is used a lot.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12458195">IO-240</key>
            <summary>FileFilterUtils can create cvsFilter and svnFilter more than once</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>

<item>
            <title>[IO-235] Bugs in CopyUtilsTest test cases?</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-235</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;testCopy_byteArrayToWriter() has the following code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;ByteArrayOutputStream baout = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ByteArrayOutputStream();
OutputStream out = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; YellOnFlushAndCloseOutputStream(baout, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// out is not used
&lt;/span&gt;Writer writer = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; java.io.OutputStreamWriter(baout, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;US-ASCII&quot;&lt;/span&gt;); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// uses baout - should it use out instead&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It looks like the Writer should be created from out rather than baout - otherwise why create out?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Similarly for&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;testCopy_inputStreamToWriter()&lt;br/&gt;
testCopy_readerToWriter()&lt;br/&gt;
testCopy_stringToWriter()&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The tests still pass if the Writer is changed to use out.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thoughts?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

            <title>[IO-231] FileUtils generate wrong exception message in isFileNewer method</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-231</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (!reference.exists()) {
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throw&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; IllegalArgumentException(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;The reference file &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;&quot;&lt;/span&gt; + file + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&apos;&lt;/span&gt; doesn&apos;t exist&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

<item>
            <title>[IO-227] AutoCloseInputStream.read() throws IOException after autoclose</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-227</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;A custom reported a problem, wherein our product was catching and logging many IOExceptions.  Upon examining the logs I see:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.io.IOException: Attempted read on closed stream.&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.httpclient.AutoCloseInputStream.isReadAllowed(AutoCloseInputStream.java:183)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.httpclient.AutoCloseInputStream.read(AutoCloseInputStream.java:107)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.io.FilterInputStream.read(FilterInputStream.java:116)&lt;br/&gt;
	at com.acme.DocPusher$BigEmptyDocumentFilterInputStream.read(DocPusher.java:679)&lt;br/&gt;
	at com.acme.CompressedFilterInputStream.fillbuff(CompressedFilterInputStream.java:96)&lt;br/&gt;
	at com.acme.CompressedFilterInputStream.read(CompressedFilterInputStream.java:67)&lt;br/&gt;
	at com.acme.Base64FilterInputStream.fillbuff(Base64FilterInputStream.java:138)&lt;br/&gt;
	at com.acme.Base64FilterInputStream.read(Base64FilterInputStream.java:115)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.io.FilterInputStream.read(FilterInputStream.java:116)&lt;br/&gt;
	at com.acme.DocPusher$AlternateContentFilterInputStream.read(DocPusher.java:609)&lt;br/&gt;
        ...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As you can see, this is a pipeline consisting of multiple FilterInputStream segments that process data flowing through the pipeline.  The source of the data is in InputStream provided by a third party plug-in component.  In our customer&apos;s situation, that InputStream is a AutoCloseInputStream returned by a Sharepoint API call.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When I saw the &quot;Attempted read on closed stream.&quot;, I was incredulous; &quot;Reading from a closed stream - that&apos;s a rookie mistake.&quot;  However, when examining the JavaDoc for AutoCloseInputStream, I read:  &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;emphasis mine&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;Proxy stream that closes and discards the underlying stream &lt;b&gt;as soon as the end of input has been reached&lt;/b&gt; or when the stream is explicitly closed.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Apple Inc. Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM 1.6.0_17; Mac OS X 10.5.8 (x86_64)&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12446943">IO-227</key>
            <summary>AutoCloseInputStream.read() throws IOException after autoclose</summary>

            <title>[IO-225] UTF-8 support on CSV</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-225</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have a struts 2 application from which user can download CSV file. &lt;br/&gt;
The problem is &lt;br/&gt;
 I download the CSV on the website then save to desktop of my computer and Open it on NOTEPAD... &lt;br/&gt;
that works fine I could still see all the utf-8 text OK with no problem, but if I open the CSV file in Microsoft EXCEL, &lt;br/&gt;
all the  utf-8 text are no longer readable. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Does any one have the solution for this, how could I make it readable in MS Excel &lt;br/&gt;
I am using org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils &lt;br/&gt;
FileUtils.writeStringToFile(file, test); &lt;br/&gt;
i also tried it with &lt;br/&gt;
FileUtils.writeStringToFile(file, test,encoding) method &lt;br/&gt;
Still the problem exists&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[IO-223] IOUtils.copy Javadoc inconsistency (return -1 vs. throw ArithmeticException)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-223</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The javadoc for IOUtils.copy says:&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;Large streams (over 2GB) will return a bytes copied value of -1 after the copy has completed since the correct number of bytes cannot be returned as an int.&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
but then it says:&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;Throws:&lt;br/&gt;
ArithmeticException - if the byte count is too large&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
This is an inconsistency since -1 is always returned if the byte count is too large. ArithmeticException is never actually thrown.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-84&quot; title=&quot;Many classes are limited to length of stream &amp;lt; 2 GB, and behave incorrectly on larger streams&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-84&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-84&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; for discussion on solving the &quot;too large byte count&quot; problem.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12440913">IO-223</key>
            <summary>IOUtils.copy Javadoc inconsistency (return -1 vs. throw ArithmeticException)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[IO-220] FileCleaningTracker Vector performs badly under load</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-220</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When subjected to heavy load, the performance of org.apache.commons.io.FileCleaningTracker degrades and becomes a bottleneck to the system.  In our case, we had over 2 millions entries on the &quot;trackers&quot; Vector.  Under these conditions, the call to trackers.remove(tracker) on line 214 becomes very inefficient as it causes the Vector to shift and reindex the remaining data.  In addition, calls to trackers.add are forced to wait on the inefficient remove operation.  With the application idle, it took several hours for the File Reaper thread to finish processing the entries on the trackers Vector.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The solution for use was to implement trackers as a HashSet instead of a Vector.  Thus line 52 was changed from:&lt;br/&gt;
    final Collection /* Tracker */ trackers = new Vector();  // synchronized&lt;br/&gt;
to&lt;br/&gt;
    final Collection /* Tracker */ trackers = Collections.synchronizedSet(new HashSet());  // synchronized&lt;br/&gt;
Imports were also change appropriately.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Using commons-io-1.4 via commons-fileupload-1.1.1 in Apache Tomcat/5.5.0 on Java 1.6.&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12438957">IO-220</key>
            <summary>FileCleaningTracker Vector performs badly under load</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

<item>
            <title>[IO-217] FileUtils.copyDirectoryToDirectory makes infinite loops</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-217</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When using FileUtils.copyDirectoryToDirectory, infinite loops has occurred.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8211; detail &amp;#8211;&lt;br/&gt;
src directory :  D:\a&lt;br/&gt;
dest directory : D:\a&lt;br/&gt;
call : FileUtils.copyDirectoryToDirectory(new File(&quot;D:\a&quot;), new File(&quot;D:\a&quot;));&lt;br/&gt;
expected result : directory D:\a\a will be created&lt;br/&gt;
actual result      : D:\a\a\a\a.......   was created&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;i guess FileUtils.copyDirectoryToDirectory causes of this result.&lt;br/&gt;
(&quot;destDir.mkdir()&quot; is done before &quot;srcDir.listFiles()&quot;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;am i calling wrong method?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;thank you.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows XP&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12433759">IO-217</key>
            <summary>FileUtils.copyDirectoryToDirectory makes infinite loops</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="tora_5675">tora yamada</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 22 Aug 2009 03:26:20 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 18:09:32 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 28 Sep 2010 23:55:56 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12896245" author="gwen" created="Sat, 7 Aug 2010 10:56:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This issue is not reproduced on revision 982449 (trunk). An exception is throwned because the source and the target directories are the same, and no infinite loop is run. &lt;br/&gt;
The aim of this issue (ie throwing an exception or creating a directory D:\a\a as required) should be precised by project leaders.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following code extract is testing the new execution.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt; 
public void testCopyDirectoryToItself() throws Exception {
        File sourceDir = new File(getTestDirectory(), &quot;source&quot;);
        if (!sourceDir.exists())
            sourceDir.mkdirs();

        File childDir = new File(sourceDir, &quot;child&quot;);
        if (!childDir.exists())
            childDir.mkdirs();
        File file = new File(sourceDir, &quot;file&quot;);
        createFile(file, 12345);

        try {
            FileUtils.copyDirectory(sourceDir, sourceDir);
            fail();
        } catch( IOException ex) {          
        }
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; 

&lt;p&gt;Hope this could help.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12903966" author="sunradiant" created="Sun, 29 Aug 2010 13:03:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have same trouble. I think this is a bug of commons-io.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When you try to copying a directory from source to sub-directory of source directory, infinite loop happens.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ex) FileUtils.copy(new File(&quot;test&quot;), new File(&quot;test/test&quot;)):&lt;br/&gt;
will fall into infinite loop.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is  why the program copy source include the destination directory.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I change the order of make destination directory and list of source directory. (attachment)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This will list the files of source directory and create the subdirectory which is the destination.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12915973" author="niallp" created="Tue, 28 Sep 2010 23:55:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I created a test case to reproduce this and Roun Lee&apos;s patch does fix it - thanks, applied:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1002424&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1002424&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-216] Delete files quietly when an exception is thrown during initialization</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-216</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;LockableFileWriter fails to report lock file deletion failure - it calls lockFile.delete() several times but fails to check the return code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;N.B. IIRC, file.delete() returns false if there was no file to delete, so any fix needs to take this into account.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12433494">IO-216</key>
            <summary>Delete files quietly when an exception is thrown during initialization</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 19 Aug 2009 17:54:51 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 18:09:30 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 28 Sep 2010 15:30:33 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Streams/Writers</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12895415" author="niallp" created="Wed, 4 Aug 2010 20:52:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;lockFile.delete() is called three times. Two of those are in the initWriter() method, trying to clean up when an exception is thrown. I assume you mean by &quot;report&quot; to throw an exception - but that would &lt;b&gt;hide&lt;/b&gt; the underlying exception that is re-thrown later. In fact I think we should use the FileUtils.deleteQuietly() method here to avoid that (attaching a patch for that).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The other time is in the close() method. We could throw an exception here, but I&apos;m not sure about that - since although it is a failure it has done its job.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Anyway, perhaps you could put forward a more concrete proposal about how this should be resolved.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12915724" author="niallp" created="Tue, 28 Sep 2010 12:37:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK I&apos;ve applied the patch I suggested and renamed this ticket to reflect that change.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12915751" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 28 Sep 2010 14:02:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The problem with ignoring the deletion failure is that the stale lock file may be detected until much later when an attempt to lock a file fails unexpectedly.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The exception does give the name of the lockFile, but it could be difficult to determine where it was created, and indeed whether it is still in use.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Not sure how best to solve this.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In the meantime, I propose to update the Javadoc to mention that the lock file could theoretically be left behind after close or on init failure.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12915787" author="niallp" created="Tue, 28 Sep 2010 15:30:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK I see you updated the JavaDoc:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1002182&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1002182&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;so resolving this as FIXED(again!)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12451266" name="IO-216-deleteQuietly.patch" size="1081" author="niallp" created="Wed, 4 Aug 2010 20:52:34 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[IO-215] FileUtils copy methods swallow date modification failures</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-215</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FileUtils.doCopyDirectory(..) and .FileUtils.doCopyFile(..) both call the setLastModified() method, but fail to check if it succeeded or not.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Surely if the caller has asked for the date to be preserved, failure to do so should be reported somehow?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12433493">IO-215</key>
            <summary>FileUtils copy methods swallow date modification failures</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 19 Aug 2009 17:50:15 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 18:09:37 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 29 Sep 2010 18:02:23 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Utilities</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12895400" author="niallp" created="Wed, 4 Aug 2010 20:20:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t see any issue with the current behaviour and am not sure what you&apos;re thinking of in terms of &quot;reporting&quot; this - I guess you mean throw an exception - but that would seem over the top for the behaviour of a minor option.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12907332" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 8 Sep 2010 17:40:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The user is able to specify whether or not to preserve file dates, and I think that failure to do so breaks the API contract - therefore an Exception should be thrown.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are some public methods which don&apos;t offer the option, but set it true internally.&lt;br/&gt;
These should probably retain the current behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12907629" author="niallp" created="Thu, 9 Sep 2010 14:02:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve used this in the past and what was most important was that the files were copied - it was &lt;b&gt;preferable&lt;/b&gt; that the last modified date was preserved, but a small loss of historical info was not critical.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I accept that your proposal is a valid alternative way of working - but since these methods have worked this way since at least Commons IO 1.1 then I&apos;m against changing the behaviour for current implementations.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have improved the documentation of the current methods regarding their behaviour wrt preserving the file dates:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=995431&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=995431&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12907714" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 9 Sep 2010 18:28:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK, point taken.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;How about adding new copyFileXX() and copyDirectoryXX() methods that do report failures?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t think there&apos;s any point in adding a boolean reportError parameter as it would only apply if preserveDates is true, so the methods would need new names.&lt;br/&gt;
Any suggestions?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s a pity that changing the return from void to boolean is not binary compatible, otherwise that would be an easy solution.&lt;br/&gt;
Maybe consider doing that for a major version update?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However the private internal copy methods could be changed to return true/false without affecting binary compatibility of the public API.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12909773" author="niallp" created="Wed, 15 Sep 2010 15:34:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I couldn&apos;t think of sensible names for new methods - for example copyFilePreserve() would probably be confusing because copyFile(File, File) does &quot;preserve&quot; and it doesn&apos;t really reflect that an exception will be thrown if not preserved - which is the difference with copyFile().  Something like copyFileThrowExceptionIfDatesNotPreserved() isn&apos;t very pleasant.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;On the &quot;returning boolean&quot; suggestion - it seems slightly unnatural/odd to return a boolean from a copy method that means &quot;dates preserved or not&quot; - the natural meaning in my mind would be to indicate whether a file was copied or not - for example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (FileUtils.copyFile(source, dest)) {
   &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// ?means dates preserved, not file copied?
&lt;/span&gt;}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Another idea would be to add an enum for the three types of behaviour:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Don&apos;t Preserve Dates&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Preserve Dates&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Preserve Dates and throw exception&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12909777" author="niallp" created="Wed, 15 Sep 2010 15:40:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Slight error in the previous patch - adding v2&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12910145" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 16 Sep 2010 13:14:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I like the enum option. It&apos;s also backward compatible AFAICS.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;BTW, the Javadoc in V2 uses &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;@param preserveFileDate ...&lt;br/&gt;
rather than&lt;br/&gt;
@param option ..&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;in a couple of places.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I also don&apos;t like if (xxx()  == false) - I think that should be if (!xxx()).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12910522" author="niallp" created="Fri, 17 Sep 2010 10:04:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attaching &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-215&quot; title=&quot;FileUtils copy methods swallow date modification failures&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-215&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-215&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;-copy-option-v3.patch that fixes the javadoc errors and adds FileUtils.copyFileToDirectory(File, File, CopyOption) method.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t like  if (!xxx()) - I think if (xxx() == false)  is better. I guess we disagree on this style.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Currently as this stands the copyDirectory() implementation when called with CopyOption.PreserveDatesThrowError will throw an error when the first File.setLastModified(long) operation fails. This could leave the copy operation in an inconsistent state with the directory only partially copied. IMO I think it would be better to complete the copy operation and throw an exception at the end. WDYT?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12910642" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 17 Sep 2010 15:54:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Agreed that failing part-way through a dir copy is not ideal.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If the private file and dir methods were changed to return false if any setLastModified fails, and true otherwise, then it should be easy to throw the appropriate error at the end.&lt;br/&gt;
Or better yet, the private doCopyDirectory method could return the File that failed, otherwise null. This would allow the Exception to identify the file which caused the first failure.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12910787" author="niallp" created="Fri, 17 Sep 2010 21:11:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attaching &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-215&quot; title=&quot;FileUtils copy methods swallow date modification failures&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-215&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-215&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;-copy-option-v4.patch - I did that, except that I used a count of the number of dates not preserved&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12910850" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 17 Sep 2010 23:38:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK, I wondered about maintaining a count. &lt;br/&gt;
Arguably more useful than the details of the first failed file, but would be nice to have the total count (and perhaps the first file) as well.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But that can be tweaked later if necessary without changing the API.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12913213" author="niallp" created="Tue, 21 Sep 2010 19:59:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attaching &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-215&quot; title=&quot;FileUtils copy methods swallow date modification failures&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-215&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-215&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;-copy-option-v5.patch - simplified patch (test case)&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Having done this work, I&apos;m still wondering whether its really required. Did you have an actual need for this - or was it just from looking at the code? If its the latter and no-one else has ever raised this, then its probably overcomplicating the API for something that no-one needs.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12916221" author="niallp" created="Wed, 29 Sep 2010 18:02:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think we should just leave this at the documentation change.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Closing as FIXED&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[IO-214] Inconsistent synchronization of fields</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-214</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The field ByteArrayOutputStream.count is always accessed in a synchronised block, apart from when the user calls toBufferedInputStream().&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This seems wrong.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Similarly for the count field in CountingOutputStream.beforeWrite(int n)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12433491">IO-214</key>
            <summary>Inconsistent synchronization of fields</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 19 Aug 2009 17:43:08 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Nov 2011 18:09:31 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 29 Sep 2010 18:00:21 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Streams/Writers</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12745220" author="niallp" created="Wed, 19 Aug 2009 21:41:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The &lt;b&gt;private&lt;/b&gt; toBufferedInputStream() method that uses the count field is only ever called by the public &lt;b&gt;static&lt;/b&gt; toBufferedInputStream() method and is a local variable only ever accessed within that static method so I can&apos;t see how it would ever need to be synchronized.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Looks like the counting OutputStream issue was introduced recently in &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-211&quot; title=&quot;Pre- and post-processing support for proxied streams&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-211&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-211&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - and the same applies to counting InputStream&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12745232" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 19 Aug 2009 22:25:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Re: ByteArrayOutputStream - good point, I&apos;d not noticed that.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Not sure why Findbugs does not detect the inconsistent synch. in InputStream, but it looks like both skip() and afterRead() need to be synchronised.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12841627" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 5 Mar 2010 00:38:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The currentBuffer and currentBuffer index fields are updated by the private method needNewBuffer(int); however this method is called by the constructor without the benefit of synchronization.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So if an instance is created in one thread and passed to another existing thread, the fields might not be published correctly.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12915793" author="niallp" created="Tue, 28 Sep 2010 15:47:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There is already &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-201&quot; title=&quot;CountingInputStream/CountingOutputStream only partially synchronized&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-201&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-201&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; for CountingInputStream/CountingOutputStream&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12916218" author="niallp" created="Wed, 29 Sep 2010 18:00:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I changed ByteArrayOutputStream&apos;s constructor:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1002791&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1002791&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The CountingInput/OutputStream issues are already logged as &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-201&quot; title=&quot;CountingInputStream/CountingOutputStream only partially synchronized&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;IO-201&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;IO-201&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Closing this as FIXED&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[IO-212] Incorrect ProxyInputStream.skip() javadoc</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-212</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The ProxyInputStream.skip() method documents the return value as &quot;the number of bytes to skipped or -1 if the end of stream&quot; when the underlying InputStream.skip() method returns &quot;the actual number of bytes skipped&quot;, i.e. never -1.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12433266">IO-212</key>
            <summary>Incorrect ProxyInputStream.skip() javadoc</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
