<item>
            <title>[IO-29] [io] NPE in FileUtils.listFiles(dir, extensions, recursive)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-29</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Calling this method with dir=&quot;c:&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;&quot; with recursion set to true on a Windows XP &lt;br/&gt;
system with NTFS partition produces NPE (debugger told line 145). I think the &lt;br/&gt;
problem is when the method reaches dirs which the user has no permission to &lt;br/&gt;
read, for instance &quot;c:\System Volume Information&quot;.&lt;br/&gt;
Maybe file.canRead() should be added somewhere before trying to go one step &lt;br/&gt;
deeper in directory tree.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thorsten&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341465">IO-29</key>

<item>
            <title>[IO-27] [io] FileUtils.toFile(URL) does not unescape %xx characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-27</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FileUtils.toFile(URL) does not properly handle URLs with %xx escaped characters,&lt;br/&gt;
which should be unescaped in the resulting File object (using&lt;br/&gt;
java.net.URLDecoder.decode(String) or similar).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following JUnit tests expose the problem:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public void testToFileHash() throws MalformedURLException&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        File expected = new File(&quot;ab#c&quot;).getAbsoluteFile();
        URL url = expected.toURI().toURL();

        File actual = FileUtils.toFile(url);
        
        assertEquals(expected, actual);
    }

&lt;p&gt;    public void testToFileQuestionMark() throws MalformedURLException&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        File expected = new File(&quot;ab?c&quot;).getAbsoluteFile();
        URL url = expected.toURI().toURL();

        File actual = FileUtils.toFile(url);
        
        assertEquals(expected, actual);
    }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows 2000&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342319">IO-27</key>
            <summary>[io] FileUtils.toFile(URL) does not unescape %xx characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[IO-23] [io] CountingInputStream doesn&apos;t implement skip()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-23</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The CountingInputStream doesn&apos;t count skipped bytes in it&apos;s count.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342158">IO-23</key>
            <summary>[io] CountingInputStream doesn&apos;t implement skip()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="roxspring">Robert James Oxspring</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 6 Apr 2005 01:43:09 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 9 Mar 2007 20:38:17 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 9 Mar 2007 20:38:17 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>

<item>
            <title>[IO-22] [io] FileUtils.cleanDirectory throws NullPointerException when File.list() fails</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-22</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;java.io.File.list() returns null if an I/O error occurs.  In practice this can&lt;br/&gt;
be triggered by trying to list the contents of a directory to which the user&lt;br/&gt;
does not have sufficient permissions (e.g. a directory with mode 0 on a&lt;br/&gt;
unix-like filesystem).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In this case, FileUtils.cleanDirectory currently throws NPE because it assumes&lt;br/&gt;
that File.list() will always return successfully.  The correct behavior should&lt;br/&gt;
be to throw IOException instead.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Following inline is a patch against trunk which resolves the issue.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Index: src/test/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtilsCleanDirectoryTestCase.java&lt;br/&gt;
===================================================================&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212; src/test/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtilsCleanDirectoryTestCase.java (revision 0)&lt;br/&gt;
+++ src/test/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtilsCleanDirectoryTestCase.java (revision 0)&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -0,0 +1,143 @@&lt;br/&gt;
+/*&lt;br/&gt;
+ * Copyright 2003,2004 The Apache Software Foundation.&lt;br/&gt;
+ *&lt;br/&gt;
+ * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the &quot;License&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
+ * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.&lt;br/&gt;
+ * You may obtain a copy of the License at&lt;br/&gt;
+ *&lt;br/&gt;
+ *      &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
+ *&lt;br/&gt;
+ * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software&lt;br/&gt;
+ * distributed under the License is distributed on an &quot;AS IS&quot; BASIS,&lt;br/&gt;
+ * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.&lt;br/&gt;
+ * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and&lt;br/&gt;
+ * limitations under the License.&lt;br/&gt;
+ */&lt;br/&gt;
+package org.apache.commons.io;&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+import java.util.ArrayList;&lt;br/&gt;
+import java.util.List;&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+import java.io.File;&lt;br/&gt;
+import java.io.IOException;&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+import org.apache.commons.io.testtools.FileBasedTestCase;&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+/**&lt;br/&gt;
+ * Test cases for FileUtils.cleanDirectory() method.&lt;br/&gt;
+ */&lt;br/&gt;
+public class FileUtilsCleanDirectoryTestCase extends FileBasedTestCase {&lt;br/&gt;
+    final File top = getLocalTestDirectory();&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+    public FileUtilsCleanDirectoryTestCase(String name) &lt;/p&gt;
{
+        super(name);
+    }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
+    private File getLocalTestDirectory() &lt;/p&gt;
{
+        return new File(getTestDirectory(), &quot;list-files&quot;);
+    }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
+    /**&lt;br/&gt;
+     * @see junit.framework.TestCase#setUp()&lt;br/&gt;
+     */&lt;br/&gt;
+    protected void setUp() throws Exception &lt;/p&gt;
{
+        top.mkdirs();
+    }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
+    /**&lt;br/&gt;
+     * @see junit.framework.TestCase#tearDown()&lt;br/&gt;
+     */&lt;br/&gt;
+    protected void tearDown() throws Exception &lt;/p&gt;
{
+        chmod(top, 775, true);
+        FileUtils.deleteDirectory(top);
+    }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
+    public void testCleanEmpty() throws Exception &lt;/p&gt;
{
+        assertEquals(0, top.list().length);
+
+        FileUtils.cleanDirectory(top);
+
+        assertEquals(0, top.list().length);
+    }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
+    public void testDeletesRegular() throws Exception &lt;/p&gt;
{
+        FileUtils.touch(new File(top, &quot;regular&quot;));
+        FileUtils.touch(new File(top, &quot;.hidden&quot;));
+
+        assertEquals(2, top.list().length);
+
+        FileUtils.cleanDirectory(top);
+
+        assertEquals(0, top.list().length);
+    }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
+    public void testDeletesNested() throws Exception &lt;/p&gt;
{
+        final File nested = new File(top, &quot;nested&quot;);
+
+        assertTrue(nested.mkdirs());
+
+        FileUtils.touch(new File(nested, &quot;file&quot;));
+
+        assertEquals(1, top.list().length);
+
+        FileUtils.cleanDirectory(top);
+
+        assertEquals(0, top.list().length);
+    }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
+    public void testThrowsOnNullList() throws Exception {&lt;br/&gt;
+        if (!chmod(top, 0, false)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
+            // test wont work if we can&apos;t restrict permissions on the
directory; skip it.
+            return;
+        }&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+        try {
+            FileUtils.cleanDirectory(top);
+            fail(&quot;expected IOException&quot;);
+        } catch (IOException e) {
+            assertEquals(&quot;Failed to list contents of &quot; + top.getAbsolutePath(),
e.getMessage());
+        }&lt;br/&gt;
+    }&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+    public void testThrowsOnCannotDeleteFile() throws Exception {&lt;br/&gt;
+        final File file = new File(top, &quot;restricted&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
+        FileUtils.touch(file);&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+        if (!chmod(top, 500, false)) {+            // test wont work if we can&apos;t restrict permissions on thedirectory; skip it.+            return;+        }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
+        try &lt;/p&gt;
{
+            FileUtils.cleanDirectory(top);
+            fail(&quot;expected IOException&quot;);
+        }
&lt;p&gt; catch (IOException e) &lt;/p&gt;
{
+            assertEquals(&quot;Unable to delete file: &quot; + file.getAbsolutePath(),
e.getMessage());
+        }
&lt;p&gt;+    }&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+    private boolean chmod(File file, int mode, boolean recurse) throws&lt;br/&gt;
IOException, InterruptedException {&lt;br/&gt;
+        List args = new ArrayList();&lt;br/&gt;
+        args.add(&quot;chmod&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+        if (recurse) &lt;/p&gt;
{
+            args.add(&quot;-R&quot;);
+        }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
+        args.add(Integer.toString(mode));&lt;br/&gt;
+        args.add(file.getAbsolutePath());&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+        Process proc;&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+        try &lt;/p&gt;
{
+            proc = Runtime.getRuntime().exec((String[]) args.toArray(new
String[args.size()]));
+        }
&lt;p&gt; catch (IOException e) &lt;/p&gt;
{
+            return false;
+        }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
+        int result = proc.waitFor();&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+        assertEquals(0, result);&lt;br/&gt;
+        return true;&lt;br/&gt;
+    }&lt;br/&gt;
+}&lt;br/&gt;
Index: src/java/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;
===================================================================&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212; src/java/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.java       (revision 291328)&lt;br/&gt;
+++ src/java/org/apache/commons/io/FileUtils.java       (working copy)&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -701,6 +701,11 @@&lt;br/&gt;
         IOException exception = null;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;         File[] files = directory.listFiles();&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+        if (files == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
+            throw new IOException(&quot;Failed to list contents of &quot; + directory);
+        }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
         for (int i = 0; i &amp;lt; files.length; i++) {&lt;br/&gt;
             File file = files&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;i&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
             try {&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342574">IO-22</key>

            <title>[IO-21] [io] IOUtils does not provide methods for converting a String to an InputStream</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-21</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This is a conversion I&apos;ve had to do on a number of occasions. Even though it is &lt;br/&gt;
fairly simple, I think utility methods in IOUtils would be useful.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341980">IO-21</key>

<item>
            <title>[IO-20] [io] IOFileFilter created by FileFilterUtils.makeCVSAware(IOFileFilter) only accept directory</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-20</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The method makeCVSAware(IOFileFilter) in FileFilterUtils returns IOFileFilter &lt;br/&gt;
that ignores CVS directories. But this IOFileFilter also ignores normal files. &lt;br/&gt;
only accepts directories.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think it should accept files and directories except directories named &quot;CVS&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I will send a path for this problem, so please see that about details.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows 2000&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341990">IO-20</key>
            <summary>[io] IOFileFilter created by FileFilterUtils.makeCVSAware(IOFileFilter) only accept directory</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

<item>
            <title>[IO-18] [io] FileUtils needs a toString that takes a filename and returns its contents as a string</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-18</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FileUtils needs a one-liner method call for reading from a file into a string,&lt;br/&gt;
something like:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;String s = FileUtils.toString(&quot;C:\\this\\that&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;data.txt&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This function would default the encoding system, so that it didn&apos;t have to be&lt;br/&gt;
added as a parameter, but would have an overloaded version to allow the user to&lt;br/&gt;
change it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12343022">IO-18</key>
            <summary>[io] FileUtils needs a toString that takes a filename and returns its contents as a string</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sstrenn@yahoo.com">Stephen Strenn</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 12 Apr 2006 00:47:43 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 9 Mar 2007 20:38:17 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 9 Mar 2007 20:38:17 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12411729" author="bayard" created="Thu, 13 Apr 2006 01:34:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Currently FileUtils has readFileToString(File, String).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So your suggestion is two-fold:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Provide a String overload for the File part.&lt;br/&gt;
2) Provide a default encoding part.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We intentionally do not do 1). It would bloat our API and is a bad habit; new File() is a good thing to do &lt;br/&gt;
so we make the user do it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m less sure on the decision (see javadoc for readFileToString) to not have a default encoding option. &lt;br/&gt;
Anyone know the reasons for that off the top of their head?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411730" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 17 Apr 2006 02:43:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;These two proposals seem like a bad idea.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) FileUtils operates on Files. Thats why its named as is. File objects are just&lt;br/&gt;
a much more reliable way to hold and manage files.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) Using a default encoding is bad practice. The default may vary between a&lt;br/&gt;
development PC and live Unix box. Also, UTF8 would be much preferred in most&lt;br/&gt;
situations.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There may be a separate call for methods that hard code the UTF8 encoding, but&lt;br/&gt;
thats a different call, and the methods would be named xxxUTF8().&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>

<item>
            <title>[IO-17] [io] delete in FileUtils sometimes fails on Windows</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-17</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The delete function in the FileUtils class will sometimes not delete a file or&lt;br/&gt;
directory on windows. This is a known bug in the VM. Ant solves this by calling&lt;br/&gt;
the GC explecitly and then wait some time. See&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://cvs.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/ant/src/main/org/apache/tools/ant/taskdefs/Delete.java?view=markup&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://cvs.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/ant/src/main/org/apache/tools/ant/taskdefs/Delete.java?view=markup&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
on how they do it.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342332">IO-17</key>
            <summary>[io] delete in FileUtils sometimes fails on Windows</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="wim.deblauwe@gmail.com">Wim Deblauwe</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 22 Jun 2005 19:34:43 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sun, 17 Sep 2006 10:44:20 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 17 Sep 2006 10:44:20 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.0</version>
                                                    <component>Utilities</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12409668" author="jeremias@apache.org" created="Fri, 24 Jun 2005 21:15:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I haven&apos;t investigated this closely but I must say that I&apos;m VERY reluctant to &lt;br/&gt;
place a System.gc() call in a library. It may be ok in certain applications &lt;br/&gt;
(like Ant) but not in Commons IO. I&apos;d rather check your application to see if &lt;br/&gt;
there are any streams that are not properly closed (in a try..finally &lt;br/&gt;
section). Or is there a bug report in Sun&apos;s bug parade that documents this &lt;br/&gt;
behaviour as a real bug?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12420775" author="bayard" created="Thu, 13 Jul 2006 10:18:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;New Ant url is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/ant/core/trunk/src/main/org/apache/tools/ant/taskdefs/Delete.java?view=markup&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/ant/core/trunk/src/main/org/apache/tools/ant/taskdefs/Delete.java?view=markup&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;GC then wait seems like a hack, but something to investigate nonetheless.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12420789" author="joehni" created="Thu, 13 Jul 2006 11:29:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Same from me: Using System.gc() in a library method is a no-no! If you cannot delete the file, it simply means, someone did not close it. So that code should be fixed!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12435305" author="scolebourne" created="Sun, 17 Sep 2006 10:44:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The general agreement here is that this is a bad idea. Also, I can find no Sun bug database report logging this issue (although there are various related misconceptions).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thus, I&apos;m closing as WontFix. Please reopen if there is a Sun bug database report, or a reproducible test case can be created.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[IO-16] DirectoryFileFilter does not work, the AbstractFileFilter bug</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-16</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Env: Java 1.4.2, commons-io-1.0.jar, Win XP&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The AbstractFileFilter&apos;s FilenameFilter&apos;s accept(File, String) method &lt;br/&gt;
implementation constructs the fileName/File (it passes to accept(File)) &lt;br/&gt;
wrongly - please see below. This causes the DirectoryFileFilter (in example, I &lt;br/&gt;
did not have time to check out the other AbstractFileFilter implementations) &lt;br/&gt;
failure since it&apos;s FileFilter implementation receives the incorrect &lt;br/&gt;
filename/File. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note I stumbled into this in Win Env. and really don&apos;t know how it works in &lt;br/&gt;
other platforms.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;v1.0 code:&lt;br/&gt;
    public boolean accept(File dir, String name) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        String filename = dir.getName() + File.separator + name;
        return accept(new File(filename));
    }

&lt;p&gt;correct code should be:&lt;br/&gt;
    public boolean accept(File dir, String name) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        String filename = dir.getPath() + File.separator + name;
        return accept(new File(filename));
    }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341683">IO-16</key>
            <summary>DirectoryFileFilter does not work, the AbstractFileFilter bug</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

                <created>Wed, 1 Sep 2004 21:44:53 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 9 Mar 2007 20:38:17 +0000</updated>

used &quot;new File(dir, name)&quot; instead.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-15] [io] Parameter check in ByteArrayOutputStream should be narrowed</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-15</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In class org.apache.commons.io.output.ByteArrayOutputStream the write(byte[] b,&lt;br/&gt;
int off, int len) method has the following check:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if ((off &amp;lt; 0) &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&apos;table-wrap&apos;&gt;
&lt;table class=&apos;confluenceTable&apos;&gt;&lt;tbody&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt; (off &amp;gt; b.length)&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt; (len &amp;lt; 0)&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt; ((off + len) &amp;gt; b.length)&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt; ((off + len) &amp;lt; 0)) {&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;


&lt;p&gt;The (off &amp;gt; b.length) check should be replaced with (off &amp;gt;= b.length). In the&lt;br/&gt;
current code incorrect offset (equal to b.lenght) can be specified if the len&lt;br/&gt;
parameter is set to 0.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342796">IO-15</key>
            <summary>[io] Parameter check in ByteArrayOutputStream should be narrowed</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="4">Incomplete</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="morisil">Kazimierz Pogoda</reporter>

                    </labels>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12411074" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 2 Jan 2006 02:22:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If (off + len == b.length) then this is OK. If (off == b.length) then len == 0,&lt;br/&gt;
so there is no data to copy.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These method checks are the same as the JDK OutputStream class.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-14] [io] Usage of dir /c instead of dir /-c in FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceWindows</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-14</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In the function freeSpaceWindows of the class FileSystemUtils, the command use is &lt;br/&gt;
dir /c (with thousand separator) instead of dir /-c (without thousand &lt;br/&gt;
separator) as state in the documentation : see line 166.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is a problem for French locale where the thousand separator is the SPACE&lt;br/&gt;
character.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for this great package !!!&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows NT&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342620">IO-14</key>
            <summary>[io] Usage of dir /c instead of dir /-c in FileSystemUtils.freeSpaceWindows</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="tledouxfr@yahoo.fr">Thomas Ledoux</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 12 Oct 2005 03:20:08 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 9 Mar 2007 20:38:16 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 9 Mar 2007 20:38:16 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.2</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12410593" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 12 Oct 2005 07:39:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Do you know if /-c works on older versions of Windows?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410594" author="tledouxfr@yahoo.fr" created="Wed, 12 Oct 2005 20:39:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #1)&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Do you know if /-c works on older versions of Windows?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t have access to an old machine. However, the following URL&lt;br/&gt;
(&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.computerhope.com/dirhlp.htm&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.computerhope.com/dirhlp.htm&lt;/a&gt;) says that neither the /c  nor the /-c&lt;br/&gt;
option exist for Windows 95, 98 and Me. They both exist for Windows NT, 2000, XP&lt;br/&gt;
and so on.&lt;/p&gt;

</comment>

<item>
            <title>[IO-13] [IO] FileUtils.toFile( URL ) doesn&apos;t deal with URL encoding</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-13</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If the URL passed to the FileUtils.toFile( URL ) method has been encoded, using&lt;br/&gt;
the numeric escapes ( e.g., space =&amp;gt; %20 ) then the returned File object cannot&lt;br/&gt;
be used to access the file on disk, as the path is wrong. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One way this can occur is when the URL is returned from&lt;br/&gt;
ClassLoader.getResource(), and the path to the resource contains spaces. Suppose&lt;br/&gt;
the following code is run from a directory containing a space (say, /tmp/with&lt;br/&gt;
space/ or d:\temp\with space&amp;#41;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static  void main( String[] args )&lt;br/&gt;
    throws Exception&lt;br/&gt;
{&lt;br/&gt;
    System.out.println( System.getProperty( &quot;java.version&quot; ) );&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    URL u = file.class.getResource( &quot;t&quot; );&lt;br/&gt;
    System.out.println( u.getFile() );&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    File f = FileUtils.toFile( u );&lt;br/&gt;
    System.out.println( f );&lt;br/&gt;
    System.out.println( f.canRead() );&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Linux:&lt;br/&gt;
1.4.1&lt;br/&gt;
/tmp/with%20space/t&lt;br/&gt;
/tmp/with%20space/t&lt;br/&gt;
false&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Windows:&lt;br/&gt;
1.4.1_06&lt;br/&gt;
/D:/temp/with%20space/t&lt;br/&gt;
D:\temp\with%20space\t&lt;br/&gt;
false&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Tested on 1.4.1, 1.4.2 and 1.5.0.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341923">IO-13</key>
            <summary>[IO] FileUtils.toFile( URL ) doesn&apos;t deal with URL encoding</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jason.madden@riskmetrics.com">Jason Madden</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 8 Dec 2004 05:48:49 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 30 May 2008 10:11:02 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 30 May 2008 10:11:02 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12408279" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 21 Feb 2005 00:58:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Change made, please retest&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408280" author="alexh.public@gmail.com" created="Wed, 22 Jun 2005 00:29:44 +0000"  >&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;
	&lt;ul&gt;
		&lt;li&gt;
		&lt;ul&gt;

		&lt;/ul&gt;

	&lt;/ul&gt;

<item>
            <title>[IO-12] [io] CountingInputStream.getCount() often returns invalid values</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-12</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In all read methods there is code like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;int found = super.read(b);&lt;br/&gt;
this.count += found;&lt;br/&gt;
return found;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;or like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;this.count++;&lt;br/&gt;
return super.read();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It is ok until we will reach EOF. In this case super.read() returns -1, and&lt;br/&gt;
decreases count in the first case, and increases in the second. In such case&lt;br/&gt;
count should not be changed. So when we have something like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;File file = new File(&quot;somefile.txt&quot;) //File with text &quot;123&quot; and no newlines&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;CountingInputStream cis = new CountingInputStream(new FileInputStream (file));&lt;br/&gt;
BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(cis));&lt;br/&gt;
while(reader.read() != -1) {}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;After this code when we call cis.getCount() it will return 2, while number of&lt;br/&gt;
bytes in read file is 3.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342028">IO-12</key>
            <summary>[io] CountingInputStream.getCount() often returns invalid values</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

<item>
            <title>[IO-11] [io] FilenameUtils.catPath shouldn&apos;t use the system separator</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-11</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I made a little change to the FilenameUtils.catPath method. In my previous&lt;br/&gt;
patch, I used the File.separator character as new separator between the 2 paths,&lt;br/&gt;
but I think it&apos;s better to use the same separator character as used in the&lt;br/&gt;
lookup path.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sorry for the extra work, I should have done some more thinking before I&lt;br/&gt;
submitted my previous patch.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Maarten&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-10</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>

<item>
            <title>[IO-8] org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.copyFile shouldn&apos;t allow to copy a file on itself</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-8</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The bug is described by a one-line code      &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FileUtils.copyFile(new File(&quot;c:/hello.txt&quot;), new File(&quot;c:/hello.txt&quot;));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Try run it and check hello.txt size before and after: you will find&lt;br/&gt;
that the file has been razed to 0 bytes.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It should be illegal to copy a file with the same path as the destination,&lt;br/&gt;
or better, with the same getCanonicalPath(), so I suggest the following &lt;br/&gt;
enhancement:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;------------ in FileUtils.java -------------&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;        //make sure we can write to destination&lt;br/&gt;
        if (destination.exists() &amp;amp;&amp;amp; !destination.canWrite()) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            String message =
                &quot;Unable to open file &quot; + destination + &quot; for writing.&quot;;
            throw new IOException(message);
        }

&lt;p&gt;        //makes sure it is not the same file        &lt;br/&gt;
        if(source.getCanonicalPath().equals(destination.getCanonicalPath())) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            String message =
                &quot;Unable to write file &quot; + source + &quot; on itself.&quot;;
            throw new IOException(message);
            
        }

&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8211; end &amp;#8211;&lt;br/&gt;
this code should be safe regarding path and canonical path: you&lt;br/&gt;
are querying OS after existence test, and anyway you are sure&lt;br/&gt;
that there is a source file and it has a canonical path.&lt;br/&gt;
(anyway getCanonicalPath throws a IOException, which is sound&lt;br/&gt;
in the context)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;hope this may help&lt;br/&gt;
daniele rizzi (drizzi@largesys.it)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341415">IO-8</key>
            <summary>org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils.copyFile shouldn&apos;t allow to copy a file on itself</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

            <title>[IO-6] [io] Problem with copyFileToDirectory(File, File)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-6</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I am running a batch application that moves around some files. &lt;br/&gt;
FileUtils.listFiles(new File(&quot;c:&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;&quot;), new PrefixFileFilter(filePrefix), new &lt;br/&gt;
NotFileFilter(new NameFileFilter(&quot;some&quot;))) works just great. But the more I &lt;br/&gt;
started load testing application I came across this strange problem. I am &lt;br/&gt;
moving around 22000 files. And While its moving around the file on some file &lt;br/&gt;
its changing file date. I am using FileUtils.copyFileToDirectory(file, todir);&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[IO-4] [io] use writeTo() instead of toByteArray in DeferredFileOutputStream.thresholdReached()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-4</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;It is better not to allocate a new buffer when writing the memory buffer to file.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;recommend using writeTo() insteand of toByteArray()&lt;br/&gt;
at DeferredFileOutputStream.java:120&lt;br/&gt;
------------&lt;br/&gt;
protected void thresholdReached() throws IOException&lt;br/&gt;
{&lt;br/&gt;
    FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream(outputFile);&lt;br/&gt;
    memoryOutputStream.writeTo(fos);&lt;br/&gt;
    diskOutputStream = fos;&lt;br/&gt;
    currentOutputStream = fos;&lt;br/&gt;
    memoryOutputStream = null;&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;br/&gt;
----------------------&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342131">IO-4</key>
            <summary>[io] use writeTo() instead of toByteArray in DeferredFileOutputStream.thresholdReached()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="gaxzerow@gmail.com">g</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 23 Mar 2005 08:34:46 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 9 Mar 2007 20:38:15 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 9 Mar 2007 20:38:15 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>1.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12408957" author="gaxzerow@gmail.com" created="Wed, 23 Mar 2005 08:44:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=14541)&lt;br/&gt;
proposed change patch&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408958" author="gaxzerow@gmail.com" created="Wed, 23 Mar 2005 09:38:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=14542)&lt;br/&gt;
fix and feature propsal&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Adding writeTo(out) used less mem when threshold has not yet been reached,&lt;br/&gt;
and it won&apos;t hurt if it has been reached.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408959" author="martinc" created="Wed, 23 Mar 2005 14:49:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve applied the first patch. Is the second patch a fix to a bug in the first &lt;br/&gt;
patch, or is it an enhancement? If the former, please attach a patch using &lt;br/&gt;
the &apos;diff -u&apos; format that the &apos;patch&apos; utility understands; if the latter, &lt;br/&gt;
please file a separate enhancement request (also with a &apos;diff -u&apos; patch).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408960" author="gaxzerow@gmail.com" created="Fri, 25 Mar 2005 09:40:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The seconde patch is an enhansment.  I&apos;ll file a separate request with proper&lt;br/&gt;
patch for it.  Recommend closing this bug it first patch is ok.  thx.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12408961" author="martinc" created="Fri, 25 Mar 2005 14:46:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied. Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12333424" name="ASF.LICENSE.NOT.GRANTED--DeferredFileOutputStream.java.patch" size="117" author="gaxzerow@gmail.com" created="Wed, 23 Mar 2005 08:44:54 +0000"/>
                            <attachment id="12333425" name="ASF.LICENSE.NOT.GRANTED--DeferredFileOutputStream.java.patch2" size="1898" author="gaxzerow@gmail.com" created="Wed, 23 Mar 2005 09:38:00 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>

<item>
            <title>[IO-3] [IO] Last modified date not preserved in FileUtils.copyFile()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-3</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;File copying using FileUtils.copyFile() does not preserve the last modified &lt;br/&gt;
date in the copy. I&apos;m not sure about other OS&apos;s, but preservation of the last &lt;br/&gt;
modified date occurs when copying from Windows Explorer or the command window &lt;br/&gt;
in a Windows environment. To add this feature to the class, just add the &lt;br/&gt;
following line at the end of FileUtils.copyFile():&lt;br/&gt;
      destination.setLastModified(source.lastModified());&lt;br/&gt;
To unit test this change, add the following to the end of &lt;br/&gt;
FileUtilsTestCase.testCopyFile1() and/or testCopyFile2():&lt;br/&gt;
        assertTrue(&quot;Check last modified date preserved&quot;, testFile1.lastModified&lt;br/&gt;
() == destination.lastModified());&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341326">IO-3</key>
            <summary>[IO] Last modified date not preserved in FileUtils.copyFile()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

                                    <version>1.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12406210" author="jeremias@apache.org" created="Sat, 13 Mar 2004 06:27:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Suggestion implemented. Thanks.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve added an additional variant of fileCopy that lets you disable the file &lt;br/&gt;
date preservation which is enabled by default (in the other two methods).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I had to add &quot;Thread.sleep(200)&quot; calls in the test cases to slow down things &lt;br/&gt;
because otherwise failures wouldn&apos;t have been detectable in fast systems.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[IO-2] [IO] FilenameUtils.catPath cannot handle &quot;\&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-2</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(sorry to assign it to the wrong component, but I cannot choose for IO)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;when I try to concat 2 paths with &quot;\&quot; as path separator instead of &quot;/&quot;, an&lt;br/&gt;
exception is thrown. I&apos;ll upload a patch for this as well as a junit test.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;e.g.: FilenameUtils.catPath(&quot;C:\\temp&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;&quot;, &quot;test&quot;) throws an exception ...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Maarten&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[IO-1] [io] API doc of FileUtils.forceMkdir(File) should mention that parent dirs are created if required</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IO-1</link>
                <project id="12310477" key="IO">Commons IO</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FileUtils.forceMkdir(File) calls File.mkdirs() to create the directory. The&lt;br/&gt;
JavaDoc of this method does not mention that any necessary but nonexistent&lt;br/&gt;
parent directories are created, too.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
